Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Endovascular Aneurysm Repair versus Open Surgical Repair in Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Management

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Participants.evidence: This multicenter randomised controlled trial included participants based on surgical fitness.

Intervention.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness of endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) compared to open surgical repair (OSR).

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness of endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) compared to open surgical repair (OSR).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was short-term mortality, assessed within 30 days post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the interventions, blinding was not feasible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 2790 participants were randomised: 1362 to EVAR and 1361 to OSR.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Short-term mortality was significantly lower in the EVAR group (1.4% vs. 4.2%, OR 0.33, 95% CI 0.20 to 0.55; P < 0.0001).

Harms.evidence: Pulmonary complications were more frequent in the OSR group (OR 0.36, 95% CI 0.17 to 0.75; P = 0.006).
